newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Weak demand hits Singapore oil storage terminals.
newsitem.headline: Weak demand hits Singapore oil storage terminals.

text.p: Oil storage operators in Singapore are adding new long-term capacity, but weak demand and lower fees have already forced one independent player to curb expansion plans, industry sources said on Tuesday.

Sources said Oiltanking Singapore Ltd has an option on a piece of land to build additional storage but does not plan to proceed with plans to expand its 600,000 cubic metre terminal by 200,000 cubic metres.
"We have no plans to expand," said a source.
The managing director of Oiltanking was not available for comment.
Tough times ahead were signalled last year, when major oil companies like Mobil and Esso and French oil company Elf failed to renew term leases.
Singapore's storage capacity for petroleum products was around 2.215 million cubic metres, but occupation may be as low as 70 percent, of which 65 percent is leased on long term contracts.
"A very small amount is being leased out on spot (short term)," said an terminal manager.
It did not make sense to store oil in a backwardated market, where nearby prices are more expensive than later prices, sources said, because it can be more profitable to sell now than later.
"In this kind of market where you have a backwardation, any one who stores is not doing the right thing," said a trader. "If any one does, it is because he does not have a choice."

Sources said storage has been mainly sought for gasoline becauswe Asia region has excess supplies and for jet-kerosene fuel, the only product in contango - where outer month cargoes are more expensive than near term cargoes - as heating demand for raises prices for the colder winter months.
"But even for winter stockpiling, the contango now is not big enough to justify the storage fees," said a trader.

Although storage fees in Singapore have in the past year come down by around a dollar to around S$5 per cubic metre a month (US$7.05), traders said they were still almost double the rates in the U.S. and Europe and needed to come down further to become economically viable.
"If they drop prices, there will be demand for the new capacity coming onstream," said a trader.
But Singapore's two other independent storage operators were optimistic for the future.
"A lot of us are bullish about regional demand and anticipate big trading," said Tay Thian Chye, a terminal manager at Dutch-owned Van Ommeren Tank Terminal.
The Asia-Pacific region's annual oil consumption growth is the highest in the world at around 5 percent, which is projected to continue to 2010 when it will exceed a quarter of world energy demand.
"We are just contributing to the infrastructure for the future growth in the oil industry, as Singapore is a centre of trading activity," said Keith Pereira, manager at Tankstore Ltd.
Tankstore's new 110,000 cubic metres storage, expected to be ready by October 1, will bring the company total capacity in Singapore up to 930,000 cubic metres, he said.
Tankstore is a joint venture between GATX Terminal Corp and Dutch Paktank Group, owned by Royal Pakhoed .
Van Ommeren is continuing with plans to add 174,000 cubic metres of storage by around April 1997.

"New storage terminals, especially in China will be competition for Singapore operators as they have the advantage of being close to the consumer markets. But traders can break bulk here," said a trader in Singapore. "It depends on your strategy. Let's just say the storage business is not having a boomtime, but it is not in dire straits."
